Daniel Plainview.Action: Works tirelessly alone in intense heat, showing determination and self-reliance.
Continues working despite harsh conditions and the death of his mule, showing focus on tasks rather than emotional response.
Endures physical hardship and injury alone, continuing to work despite pain and exhaustion.
Focuses intensely on mining and gathering silver ore, showing determination and self-reliance rather than social connection.
Drags himself repeatedly across the desert, pushing a cart, showing determination and endurance.
Works alongside men digging a well, involved in collective labor despite harsh conditions.
Passes out from toxic fumes while working and is revived by a colleague who smacks him awake.
Studies a newspaper clipping with men, pointing and discussing it together, indicating a collaborative approach.
Drags himself repeatedly across the desert pushing a cart, demonstrating physical endurance and persistence.
Lays on the floor watching the assay process and tallying value of silver, showing attention to detail and understanding of resource value.
Works with others to dig a well, using knowledge of equipment like pulley and loading/unloading methods, indicating practical skill and leadership.
Passes out inside a well due to fumes, requiring assistance to be revived.
Stands with others over a newspaper clipping, discussing and analyzing crude derrick technology to understand how it works.
Operates the drill himself, showing hands-on involvement and coaching Ailman during the recovery of the drill piece.
Watches the drill slip and fall without visible frustration or blame, then encourages the recovery effort.
Looks at baby H.W. after Ailman's accidental death, picks him up and holds him awkwardly, then puts him back in the basket and looks at him again.
Successfully leads operation to extract oil, oversees the collection and storage process efficiently.
While working underground with Ailman, detects a failing timber support (shows alertness).
Experiences shock and paralysis when Ailman is fatally injured and sprayed with blood.
After the accident, responsibly picks up and cares for the baby H.W., showing concern and protectiveness.
Pours whiskey on his finger and puts it in baby H.W.'s mouth to soothe him, though ineffectively; allows the baby's mother to breastfeed to calm the child.
Sleeps sitting on the floor next to the baby, showing physical closeness but limited active care.
Addresses an audience confidently about his success and warns them to be cautious about scammers and speculators.
Emphasizes personal involvement and trustworthiness of his own men, insisting on quality and reliability in work.
Displays composure and calmness in the face of aggressive interruption.
Boasts about his advantages over competitors and guarantees backing his word, hinting at confidence but also self-promotion.
Advises the group to take a smaller share of royalty for a bigger long-term gain, speaking humbly as an oil man.
Leaves the room silently amid chaos without attempting to intervene or calm the fighting.
Calmly advises the crowd on the importance of timely cooperation and advises taking a smaller share of royalty for a bigger collective gain, demonstrating industry knowledge and strategic thinking.
Walks out of a chaotic negotiation without attempting to manage or control the escalating disorder among the families.
Refuses to take the lease from Prescott, dismissing his pleas and walking away without compromise.
Speaks directly and clearly to Mr. Bankside, avoiding wasting time and explaining the situation and urgency frankly.
Offers Bankside a smaller royalty due to distance but adds a $1000 bonus, guarantees drilling start within 10 days.
Mentions the death of his wife and raising his son alone when asked by Mrs. Bankside.
Answers Paul's questions patiently and allows him to sit before speaking further.
States he enjoys all faiths and doesn't belong to a particular church when asked by Paul.
Responds cautiously and vaguely about price and details, showing guardedness.
Maintains a wary, questioning stance with Paul Sunday, asking clarifying questions before making any commitments.
Avoids revealing personal information or showing vulnerability when questioned.
Acknowledges uncertainty with honest statements like 'that depends' and 'lots of things' when asked about buying land prices.
Does not rush into deals or disclose what he knows prematurely.
Responds vaguely about religious affiliation, which may suggest evasiveness rather than clarity.
Offers an initial lower payment ($100) with the promise of a bonus if the lease looks promising, then negotiates up to $400 before agreeing to pay $600 with Fletcher's help.
Acknowledges and affirms that H.W. is his son when Paul asks.
Engages in a direct, pragmatic negotiation with Paul Sunday without displaying friendliness or condescension.
Negotiates with Paul Sunday by initially offering a lower amount and proposing a conditional bonus based on prospect evaluation.
Refers to geological factors (alkali, sulphur) through inquiry to assess land potential before committing to purchase.
Concedes to pay the full amount after Paul insists and threatens to go elsewhere, pooling own and Fletcher’s money to close the deal quickly.
Asks Paul Sunday detailed questions about his family and land, showing some interest and attentiveness.
Offers Paul Sunday a place to stay for the night.
Threatens Paul Sunday that if he lies about the oil, Daniel will come after him and take more than his money back.
Carefully gathers detailed local geographic and family information before investing in drilling operations.
Makes a pointed threat to ensure honesty and protect his investment.
Offers hospitality to Paul despite his reluctance, maintaining control of the situation.
Does not appear rushed or careless in assessing the oil prospects; allows local knowledge to guide his decisions.
Catches and helps HW when he starts to fall with the camping equipment.
Instructs HW to remember silence and to walk beside him, not behind him.
Politely greets Abel Sunday and introduces himself and his son.
Carefully plans and prepares for potentially difficult terrain by bringing heavy camping equipment and instructing his son to remain silent and walk beside him.
Supports and assists his son when he starts to fall under the weight of camping equipment, showing attentiveness and care during a physically demanding situation.
Approaches a stranger cautiously and introduces himself confidently with clear intent, demonstrating social confidence and purposeful action.
Politely and confidently initiates conversation, assesses resources (asks for water, bread, potatoes), and establishes camping spot without imposing on hosts.
Insists on doing their own camping rather than accepting help, showing self-reliance and leadership.
Does not detect Eli's failure to bring water promptly, missing a minor social cue or an opportunity to assert control.
Politely thanks Abel Sunday for his hospitality and expresses a desire to work with his son on making a fire.
States that his 'church is called The Church of the World,' avoiding explaining or engaging in a meaningful religious conversation.
States that friendship and business are how they get to know a man, suggesting faith conversations come later.
Answers Eli's question about earthquakes seriously and respectfully, attributing them to God's power.
Reassures Eli by saying 'No, son. We haven't' when asked about drunkenness and lying, showing protective sincerity towards family.
Engages in a quiet activity with his son hunting quail early in the morning.
Encourages his son ('Go get 'em') after he shoots a quail, showing supportive behavior.
Responds to Eli's question about earthquakes with a composed, theologically consistent answer reflecting knowledge of his faith.
Encourages H.W. during quail hunting, showing leadership and mentorship.
No clear mistakes or failures in the given excerpt; overall composed and capable behavior.
Examines the oil slick carefully and explains its significance with interest.
Shows practical knowledge by explaining to H.W. the purpose of putting pigs near sulphur water to cure mange.
Enters abandoned house, respectfully observes religious artifacts before leaving.
Offers Mother Sunday to stay on the land with farming rights for 99 years for $10/year after purchase
Offers $5000 signing bonus to Eli and the Church if well produces oil, but refuses to share mineral rights
Challenges Eli to find someone else to invest and drill for oil, indicating self-interest and transactional attitude
Negotiates a lease with Mother Sunday, offering farming rights and a lease for ninety-nine years at ten dollars a year.
Engages in a tense negotiation with Eli about sharing mineral rights, ultimately offering a $5,000 signing bonus contingent on productive drilling.
Hesitates and does not clearly quantify what he would give for mineral rights, showing some uncertainty or unwillingness to commit.
Challenges Eli about the risks and costs of drilling to emphasize his control and discourage demands.
Refuses to fully share mineral rights despite community pressure, demonstrating strategic firmness but also potential inflexibility.
Expresses willingness to support Eli's church with a bonus.
Shows mild concern when H.W. falls after Eli pushes him and checks if he is alright.
Encourages Eli by telling him he might have a nice car like his someday.
Barely reacts to Eli pushing H.W., possibly accidental/on purpose, suggesting tolerance or avoidance of conflict.
Conducts business with Al Rose in a polite and straightforward manner.
Offers to support the church with conditions, indicating strategic thinking and negotiation skills.
Proposes drawing up contracts and moving forward with drilling, showing decisiveness and readiness to act.
Handles the logistics of moving equipment and car efficiently.
Addresses H.W.'s fall with calm concern, maintaining control over the situation.
Drives off confidently after separating from Eli, indicating self-assurance in his direction.
Engages with the real estate agent by requesting a map, making notes and inquiring about parcels of land, showing proactive planning and investigation.
Offers Al Rose a fair price and promises a commission plus additional percentage, emphasizing not to inflate prices and to act quietly to avoid speculation.
Insists on controlling the entire purchasing process, carrying all forms and instructions himself, showing distrust and micromanagement.
Outlines a clear, strategic plan for land acquisition, emphasizing low prices and discretion to avoid price inflation.
Prepares legal documents on the spot and ensures that his agent is well equipped to close deals immediately.
Offers a clear financial incentive to his agent while maintaining control over the transaction.
Politely exchanges greetings and small talk with other oil men and the train depot man, uses son to build connections.
Asks the right people for local contacts to facilitate well drilling and road construction, showing knowledge of local business and resources.
Makes an efficient phone call to coordinate drilling efforts, delegating tasks to his son, demonstrating clear communication and leadership.
Greets and interacts confidently and courteously with rival oil men, showing social awareness and professional conduct.
Plans ahead by ensuring a proper well is drilled with specific instructions, reflecting foresight and technical competence.
Expresses preference for Gene Blaize to prosper rather than others; says 'I like you Gene' and advises him honestly about opportunities.
Responds kindly and sincerely to Wrightsman's teasing compliment about his son’s appearance, showing openness and gratitude.

Finds interesting prospects and advises Gene Blaize strategically to look east where there are still opportunities, showing awareness of the competitive landscape and a willingness to share a strategic tip to a potential rival.
Engages politely and confidently in social interaction with Whrightsman, handling the comment about his son's looks with humor and grace.
Compliments H.W. on his work on the water well and expresses love to his son.
Dismisses a potential conversation with Mr. Bandy as a waste of time, prioritizing transactions over personal connection.
Reviews maps and listens to H.W. attentively, praises H.W. for his work on the water well, and expresses affection and encouragement.
Critiques Al Rose's assessment of land purchases as 'not successful' despite their apparent success, showing attention to detail and high standards.
Dismisses an opportunity to personally speak with Mr. Bandy, relying on Al Rose's reports and showing impatience.
Dismisses the potential seller rudely and refuses to engage in friendly conversation.
Acknowledges and thanks Al Rose for his good work.
Watches Eli glad-handing the workers carefully, showing suspicion and distance.
Agrees to allow Eli to bless the well and be introduced, showing some cooperation.
Agrees to introduce Eli with respectful words and delegates speaking order.
Compliments Howard on cleaning and preparing the house.
Refuses to practice the speech introduction despite Eli's suggestion.
Agrees to introduce Eli and remembers the words without needing them written down.
Declines to practice the introduction with Eli, despite the importance of the event.
Organizes and executes a public 'spudding in' ceremony with key town figures and workers present.
Makes a public speech emphasizing community, working together, praying together, and sharing wealth together.
Acknowledges Mary Sunday in the speech by naming the well after her and saying 'God Bless Us All.'
Passes over Eli and signals his son H.W. to start the drilling, showing deference to his son in front of others.
At small celebration, compliments Mary on her dress and asks if she is happy he came; reassures her about no more hitting and offers protection.
Makes a confident and skillful speech to the community that emphasizes collaboration, faith, and shared wealth, effectively rallying people around the drilling project.
Passes the signal to start drilling to his son H.W., demonstrating control and trust in his team, and effectively initiates the drilling process.
Appears to have had a little too much to drink at the evening celebration, which could indicate a lapse in personal restraint or professionalism.
Speaks kindly to Mary, reassuring her about her father's behavior, showing some emotional awareness and protective instincts, though the tone is somewhat ambiguous.
Gently holds a child's shoulder kindly and tells her no more hitting.
Tells the child to go play and not to come back in a harsh manner.
Does not respond promptly or help when Ben Blaut tries to wake him regarding a man fallen into the well.
Responds immediately upon being informed of the emergency by Ben Blaut and opens his eyes quickly.
Does not physically move or take immediate action when woken to urgent news of Joe Gundha falling into the well.
Expresses intense frustration and despair over the dangers and futility of the oil business, lamenting how people fail to help themselves.
Organizes workers to build a claw device to retrieve the drowned man's body and gives safety instructions to prevent future accidents.
Walks off immediately after giving instructions, showing detachment from the emotional impact of the death.
Organizes and directs workers to use a customized three-pronged grab to retrieve a drowned man's body from a narrow, dangerous well.
Expresses frustration vocally and seems emotionally overwhelmed, saying he wants out of the business and lamenting people's unwillingness to help themselves.
Establishes a safety protocol by instructing men to place a cover on the well's cellar opening if any man goes down, demonstrating procedural awareness.
Packs the religious belongings of the dead Joe Ghunda carefully, looking closely at them before packing.
Observes Eli's intense and aggressive religious preaching and healing ritual silently without intervention.
Carefully packs and examines the religious belongings of Joe Ghunda before moving on, showing attention to detail.
Passively watching Eli’s fervent church service without intervening or reacting strongly.
Acknowledges the tragedy at the well and addresses the need for rest and discipline among workers to avoid careless mistakes.
Negotiates with Eli to have him speak at the burial, showing social tact and plans to maintain good relations.
Shows pragmatic understanding of the impact of distractions (like religious visits) on worker productivity and oil extraction.
Does not confront Eli's criticism directly about the accident being avoidable, instead responds diplomatically and redirects focus.
Engages in conversation about the church's 'Third Revelation' with Eli, showing some openness to dialogue.
Kicks the broken piece of pipe across the floor and off the derrick, saying 'go fish,' showing impatience and disregard for workers' efforts.
Takes a break alone, smoking a cigarette off to the side, indicating isolation and lack of social warmth.
Allows Abel to sit beside him silently without greeting or warmth.
Responds coldly and dismissively to Abel's attempts at friendly religious counsel and concern.
Smiles briefly when the broken piece is found, sharing a moment of success with the crew.
Directly insults Abel calling him a 'weak little man' and tells him to stay away.
Focuses on business and land acquisition over any personal or emotional connection with Abel.
Keeps the crew persistently fishing for a broken piece for almost three weeks until success is achieved.
Silently endures Abel's moral and religious criticism without losing focus on the task.
Successfully retrieves the broken piece from the well, leading to the crew's celebration.
Dismisses Abel's faith and moral authority harshly right after a significant success.
Appears confident and assertive in his final statements to Abel, reinforcing control over the situation.
Smiles at Mary and HW and warmly asks 'How are my kids? how’s my family?'
Does not immediately notice HW's accident, focusing instead on the gusher and ordering 'Lights out!'
Smiles warmly and asks about his family, showing human connection but no direct task competence.
Works with Fletcher and men to loosen stuck casing using a jar tool, demonstrating technical knowledge and leadership.
Fails to notice HW's accident and injury immediately, focusing instead on managing the gusher.
Commands everyone to evacuate by shouting 'LIGHTS OUT! LIGHTS OUT!' after the gusher eruption, showing quick response under pressure.
Carries H.W. to safety from the burning derrick, urgently checks on him, tries to calm him down.
Instructs base camp families to watch after H.W. and keep him safe.
Leaves H.W. who is in distress and screaming, unable to fully soothe him.
Runs up to the derrick floor and orders everyone to turn the lights out to prevent further danger.
Watches the fire coming toward him and is unable to move, frozen in shock.
Quickly grabs and carries H.W. to safety amidst chaos.
Attempts to calm H.W. down during his panic but fails.
Instructs base camp families to watch after H.W. and keep him safe while he leaves to handle the emergency.
Pushes HW down and goes outside, showing disregard for his son’s feelings.
Exhibits excitement and happiness after successfully extinguishing the oil fire, demonstrating engagement with work but no direct warmth towards others.
Barks directions towards taming the oil fire; organizes men and uses dynamite skillfully to extinguish the blaze efficiently.
Pushes HW down and goes back outside without apparent concern for his son's safety or feelings.
Rocks HW in his arms, whispering 'I love you' repeatedly to comfort him during a hysterical episode.
Tries to hold down and calm HW during his violent outburst at the doctor.
Tells Al Rose there is an ocean of oil under their feet despite the ruined well, showing determination rather than empathy.
Offers to build a school and provide a high salary and home for the teacher to educate his son locally.
Refuses to send his son to San Francisco despite teacher’s advice about socialization and need to learn to deal with circumstances.
Dismisses and orders the teacher to leave when she refuses his offer, cutting off her contact with his son.
Slaps Eli multiple times violently in front of witnesses without provocation.
Mocks Eli's supposed spiritual powers while physically abusing him.
Threatens to make Eli leave and 'bury him under ground'.
Cautiously verifies Henry’s identity by requesting identification and a letter before accepting him as his brother.
Initially silent and guarded, showing control over emotions and assessing the situation carefully.
Quickly accepts Henry after verifying legitimacy and shows warmth with handshake and hug, indicating emotional intelligence and ability to balance personal and business matters.
No clear indication of confusion or losing control in the interaction despite surprise, maintaining composure.
Engages Henry in conversation about his life, showing some personal interest.
States he has his own family and concerns, setting a boundary.
Pours whiskey into milk out of sight from H.W., then kindly encourages H.W. to drink the milk.
Carries the passed-out H.W. to bed, demonstrating care.
Engages Henry in conversation to gather detailed information about his background and motives, demonstrating awareness and control.
Refuses to consider going back home, showing focus and commitment to his own goals.
Subtly administers whiskey in milk to H.W. out of sight, indicating careful planning and protective skill.
Maintains a hard, watchful demeanor when assessing Henry, showing psychological acuity.
Admits to feeling sick about manipulating people to get what he wants
Expresses desire to move far away from everyone
Says he sees the worst in people and built his hatreds up over the years
Acknowledges that having Henry gives him a second breath and he couldn't keep doing this on his own
Avoids talking about the boy’s mother
States that he has worked people over and gotten what he wants from them, demonstrating resourcefulness and assertiveness.
Expresses desire to make enough money to move far away from everyone, showing long-term planning and ambition.
Avoids discussing the boy’s mother and personal matters, indicating emotional guardedness but possibly a lack of openness or transparency.
Claims to see the worst in people and not need to look past that to get all he needs, suggesting a cynical but shrewd understanding of human nature.
Admits to building up hatreds over the years and needing company to keep going, revealing underlying vulnerability and possible emotional instability.
Observes social scene from a slight distance, maintains composure among drunk oil men.
Has an intimate encounter with the local vixen woman, then tidies appearance and leaves discreetly.
Wakes up during the fire, escapes the burning house, and is visibly concerned by H.W.'s dangerous behavior.
Shouts in anger and frustration at H.W. after the fire, demanding an explanation for risking their lives and home.
Wakes up in time to escape the burning house by smashing a window to get out.
Fails to prevent or detect H.W.'s act of setting the fire, resulting in the destruction of the cottage.
Hugs H.W. very tight and kisses his head repeatedly before leaving on the train.
Says to H.W., 'I'll be right back... you stay here.' showing concern and attempt to reassure.
Leaves H.W. alone on the train, walking away without looking back, causing distress to H.W.
On the train departure, remains distant and emotionally detached despite H.W.'s screams.
In drunken state, asserts 'He’s not my son' and displays self-loathing and vulnerability.
Hugs H.W. tightly and kisses his head repeatedly, showing emotional connection before leaving on the train.
Leaves H.W. on the train and walks away with a long, deliberate pace as the train departs.
Appears deeply emotional and vulnerable, admitting inability to father a child and expressing personal doubts while drunk.
Introduces Henry as his brother to business associates, presenting a united front.
Thanks Tilford for asking about his son, showing polite acknowledgement.
Focuses discussion on business and deal-making, quickly counters Tilford’s claims about proven wells, indicating competitiveness and suspicion.
Negotiates with Standard Oil representatives and corrects their misinformation about the number of proven wells, showing awareness and confidence.
Quickly accepts the offer of $150,000 for Coyote Hills without evident hesitation or counteroffer.
Threatens Tilford violently for discussing his son and offering to buy him out.
Refuses to be reasonable or open to negotiation, showing distrust and aggression.
Refuses to allow investigation into Henry's background, asserting strong knowledge and control over personal matters.
Expresses regret that a hospital was not built, indicating missed opportunities to improve relations and infrastructure.
Confidently dismisses Fletcher’s suggestion to pacify rival Eli by paying him, showing strategic prioritization of resources.
Dismisses a woman's refusal to build a hospital as 'stupid.'
Prepares methodically by loading crude oil samples and marking a pipeline route with Henry.
Engages politely yet succinctly with William, indicating intent to speak with his grandfather without showing friendliness or warmth.
Introduces brother Henry to Press St. Clair, maintains polite and cordial interaction.
Engages in professional discussion about pipelines and oil with Union Oil men.
Jokes crudely about beating a wife and a free whore with a group, eliciting laughter.
Shares a nostalgic memory about wanting a beautiful house and children as a boy, displaying a rare glimpse of vulnerability.
Plans to build a better house away from the smell of current surroundings, indicating desire for improvement and comfort.
Refers to socializing and drinking with Henry, showing camaraderie in a casual sense.
Watches Henry closely after mentioning the Peachtree dance, possibly signaling distrust or suspicion.
Engages in business discussions with Union Oil representatives using maps, drawings, and crude samples, showing his preparation and knowledge.
Makes a clever, provocative joke about Standard Oil and a free whore, demonstrating social confidence and sharp wit in a business setting.
Reflects nostalgically about the house he admired as a boy and expresses clear, ambitious personal goals about building a better life, indicating vision and confidence.
Pauses and watches Henry intently after a reference to the Peachtree dance, showing attentiveness and caution regarding his companion's reaction.
Spends a relaxed moment floating in the ocean with Henry, demonstrating ability to compartmentalize and balance work with downtime.
Keeps a careful watch on Henry swimming alongside him, showing suspicion and paranoia.
Observes Henry quietly while Henry behaves drunkenly and loudly at the bar, showing restraint and non-confrontation.
Engages Henry in a somewhat teasing and cynical conversation about women and children, implying distrust and a hard-nosed attitude.
Carefully monitors Henry while swimming, showing vigilance and awareness.
Observes Henry discreetly in the bar while Henry is drunk and loud, demonstrating patience and strategic observation.
Questioning Henry about his personal life to gather information and assess trustworthiness.
Begins to show paranoia about Henry, possibly impairing objective judgment.
Considers business help from Henry and responds neutrally.
Sleeps near Henry with a revolver by his side, indicating suspicion.
Questions Henry persistently about personal details, showing distrust.
Shoots Henry in the head after hearing about a supposed brother and betrayal.
Kills Henry and buries him in a shallow grave, then drinks excessively and ignores the memory of his brother.
Attempts to lease land from Bandy, speaking pragmatically and persistently despite previous rejection.
Puts Henry’s body in a shallow grave and carefully disposes of evidence like the horse.
Reads Henry’s journal and studies key details like the identification and notes.
Drinks heavily during the process and eventually passes out.
Despite exhaustion and hangover, approaches Bandy to negotiate leasing land, showing persistence and clear purpose.
Offers to pay Bandy money to persuade him, showing transactional rather than sincere engagement.
Questions religious appeals with sarcasm ('my sin of..what? drilling?'), indicating skepticism and insincerity.
Comes to church seeking a fresh start and Eli's blessing, showing some openness to change or reconciliation.
Approaches Eli on stage and admits he is a sinner, gets down on his knees trying to say a prayer despite discomfort.
Struggles and hesitates to sincerely confess his sins, visibly steaming and pressured by the crowd.
Approaches the stage in the church and admits to being a sinner when asked by Eli.
Struggles to say the required confession aloud and appears uncomfortable and steamed while pressured by the crowd and Eli.
Repeats confessions and appears to be in distress but participates sincerely in the religious ritual.
Seeks to 'get away' from the ritual, showing discomfort and possible desire to escape emotional vulnerability.
Repeats confessions and responses under pressure, showing internal conflict and submission during a public humiliation ritual.
Accepts public religious ceremony, is physically embraced and shown warmth by others, and begins to feel warmth from the crowd.
Allows others to touch and comfort him in a religious ritual, showing some openness to connection.
No explicit personal reciprocation of warmth or friendliness toward others shown in the excerpt; mostly receives warmth but internal response is ambiguous.
Accepts Holy Spirit baptism and gains the warmth and acceptance of the community around him, showing ability to influence and be accepted by others.
Arranges for premier accommodations and a skilled instructor (George Reynolds) to teach his son, showing planning and investment in his son's education and future.
Grabs H.W., kisses and hugs him, whispers to him gently and kindly.
Sits with H.W. at a fancy restaurant, ensuring he has a good meal and shows concern if he is hungry.
Expresses frustration but tries to connect by asking H.W. if he can hear and see him.
States he needs H.W.'s help to build the company, implying trust and dependence.
Abruptly leaves H.W. at the restaurant to confront an adversary (H.M. Tilford) aggressively.
Supervises construction of the pipeline actively, working in the sun with effort and overseeing the project.
Refuses a million-dollar offer from Standard for the Little Boston leases, showing strategic decision-making to hold out for better deals.
Arranges for a teacher and support for his son H.W. to ensure his well-being and development, indicating forward planning.
Leaves H.W. abruptly to confront H.M. Tilford at the restaurant, showing initiative and a willingness to directly confront opposition.
Makes a deal with Union to ensure his son's safety and happiness, asserting control over his family and business matters confidently.
Dismisses Tilford's opinion aggressively but remains firm and clear about his decisions regarding his son and business.
Daniel continues to 'babble away,' with his son H.W. hearing nothing, possibly indicating a failure to communicate effectively in that moment.
Questions HW and George sharply, refuses to allow private conversation, implying distrust.
Confronts HW about using company resources improperly and suspects disloyalty.
Responds skeptically and hostilely to HW’s confession of love and plans to leave, calling him competitor and dismissing his intentions.
Immediately senses disloyalty and questions H.W./George directly and confidently, showing awareness and control of the situation.
Recognizes potential competition quickly and assesses it as a 'misstep', showing insight into business risks.
Accuses and confronts an associate firmly and without hesitation, demonstrating decisiveness in leadership.
Fails to find a diplomatic way to address H.W.'s announcement, potentially escalating conflict unnecessarily.
Calls H.W. and George 'not my sons,' insults them harshly, accuses them of betrayal and being hateful.
Expresses deep disappointment and anger towards H.W. and George, refusing to acknowledge any familial bond.
Insists on direct communication and challenges H.W. to speak for himself rather than through the dog.
Engages in emotionally charged verbal confrontation with H.W./George, revealing deep personal conflict and lack of effective emotional control.
Passed out drunk alone in his mansion's basement, showing neglect of self and others.
Comes to only after being woken repeatedly by servant and Eli Sunday, showing withdrawal and detachment.
Comes staggering in drunk, passes out in his own house, showing loss of control and inability to manage himself or his estate effectively.
Eventually responds to the servant and Eli Sunday, takes a drink and sits up, showing some recovery and awareness despite his state.
Expresses polite interest in Eli's news and business proposal.
Agrees to work with Eli on drilling the lease.
Demands Eli admit to being a False Prophet and that God is superstition as a condition for business.
Engages in negotiation with Eli, sets unexpected condition challenging Eli's faith, testing his resolve before agreeing to business.
Expresses confidence about quick drilling turnaround.
Does not immediately reveal true intentions behind challenging Eli's faith, maintaining strategic ambiguity.
Calls Eli a fraud, belittles him repeatedly, physically assaults him by smacking and throwing him across the room, mocks his faith and desperation.
Identifies Paul as the true source of valuable information and claims to have successfully taken advantage of it by obtaining the land.
Uses a vivid metaphor to assert dominance and explain how he exploits others' resources (the milkshake straw analogy).
Physically assaults Eli and verbally abuses him in a tense confrontation.
Physically assaults Eli, pins him down, and fatally wounds him, then drags his body away.
Confidently asserts intellectual and spiritual superiority over Eli, declaring himself 'smarter, older, and wiser' and 'the third revelation.'
Physically attacks Eli and kills him in a violent, brutal manner without apparent hesitation or remorse.
